1.1 The theorem of Total Probability and Bayes' theorem

To establish these results we start with the definition of a partition of a sample space.

A partition of a sample space

The collection of events \(A_1,A_2,\dots,A_n\) is said to partition a sample space \(S\) if

  1. \(A_1\cup A_2 \cup\cdots\cup A_n = S\);
  2. \(A_i\cap A_j = \varnothing\) for all \(i, j\) with \(i\neq j\);
  3. \(A_i\neq\varnothing\) for all \(i\).

In essence, a partition is a collection of non-empty, non-overlapping subsets of a sample space whose union is the sample space itself. The definition is illustrated by the figure below.


Figure: Partition of a set.

If \(B\) is any event within \(S\) then we can express \(B\) as the union of subsets:\[B = (B \cap A_1) \cup (B \cap A_2) \cup\cdots\cup(B \cap A_n)\]The definition is illustrated in the figure below in which an event B in S is represented by the shaded region.


Figure: A subset in a set partition.

The bracketed events \((B\cap A_1),(B\cap A_2),\dots,(B\cap A_n)\) are mutually exclusive (if one occurs then none of the others can occur) and so, using the addition law of probability for mutually exclusive events:\[\mathbb{P}(B) = \mathbb{P}(B\cap A_1) + \mathbb{P}(B\cap A_2) +\cdots+ \mathbb{P}(B\cap A_n)\]Each of the probabilities on the right-hand side may be expressed in terms of conditional probabilities:\[\mathbb{P}(B\cap A_i) = \mathbb{P}(B|A_i)\mathbb{P}(A_i)\quad\text{for all }i.\]Using these in the expression for \(\mathbb{P}(B)\), above, gives:\[\begin{aligned}\mathbb{P}(B) &= \mathbb{P}(B|A_1)\mathbb{P}(A_1) + \mathbb{P}(B|A_2)\mathbb{P}(A_2) +\cdots+ \mathbb{P}(B|A_n)\mathbb{P}(A_n)\\ &= \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{P}(B|A_i)\mathbb{P}(A_i).\end{aligned}\]This is the theorem of Total Probability. A related theorem with many applications in statistics can be deduced from this, known as Bayesâ€™ theorem.
